sources: Barry Rice, About Humidity, The Carnivorous Plant FAQ (2007)
http://www.sarracenia.com/faq/faq3440.html

1.name: Byblis liniflora
sources: Brian Barnes, Growing Byblis successfully, International Carnivorous Plant Society
http://www.carnivorousplants.org/howto/GrowingGuides/Byblis.php

2.name: Darlingtonia californica
sources: John Brittnacher, Growing Darlingtonia californica, International Carnivorous Plant Society
http://www.carnivorousplants.org/howto/GrowingGuides/Darlingtonia.php
Jennifer Brownfield, Rearing Cobras, Carnivorous Plant Newsletter 14(3):78-80 (1985)
http://www.carnivorousplants.org/cpn/articles/CPNv14n3p78_80.pdf

3.name: Utricularia subulata
sources: Barry Rice, About terrestrial Utricularia, The Carnivorous Plant FAQ (2007)
http://www.sarracenia.com/faq/faq5583.html

4.name: Pinguicula lusitanica
sources: Growing warm temperate Pinguicula, International Carnivorous Plant Society
http://www.carnivorousplants.org/howto/GrowingGuides/Pings_WarmTemp.php

5.name: Proboscidea parviflora var. hohokamiania
sources: Growing Ibicella and Proboscidea, International Carnivorous Plant Society
http://www.carnivorousplants.org/howto/GrowingGuides/Ibicella.php

6.name: Drosera rotundifolia
l: as much as possible; will flower >16 hr photoperiod
sources: Aaron May, Drosera rotundifolia 'Charles Darwin', The Sundew Grow Guides
http://www.growsundews.com/sundews/rotundifolia_charles_darwin.html

7.name: Drosera filiformis tracyi
t: USDA zone 6-9, with winter protection. Most likely need a wintering to germinate seeds.
sources: John Brittnacher, Growing Drosera filiformis and Drosera tracyi, International Carnivorous Plant Society
http://www.carnivorousplants.org/howto/GrowingGuides/D_filiformis.php

8.name: Drosera capensis
sources: Aaron May, Drosera capensis varieties, The Sundew Grow Guides
http://www.growsundews.com/sundews/Drosera_capensis.html

9.name: Sarracenia leucophylla
t: needs seasons, summer - mid 90's, winter - can tolerate freezing
sources: Growing Sarracenia leucophylla, International Carnivorous Plant Society
http://www.carnivorousplants.org/howto/GrowingGuides/S_leucophylla.php

10.name: Nepenthes (N. maxima x N. northiana)
t: fairly wide temperature range. It does best with warm to hot days and cool nights, but avoid longer periods of cold night time temperatures
l: consistent, low-intensity illumination, or at least indirect sunlight
sources: David P. Evans, Nepenthes maxima ‘Lake Poso’, Carnivorous Plant Newsletter 38(1):12-22 (2009)
http://www.carnivorousplants.org/cpn/Species/v38n1p12_22.html
Jeff Shafer, Cultivation of Nepenthes Northiana, Carnivorous Plant Newsletter 32(2):49-51 (2003)
http://www.carnivorousplants.org/cpn/articles/CPNv32n2p49_51.pdf

11.name: Sarracenia purpurea purpurea
t: most cold hardy of the Sarracenia, can survive USDA zone 5 and colder
sources: John Brittnacher, Growing Sarracenia purpurea and S. rosea, International Carnivorous Plant Society
http://www.carnivorousplants.org/howto/GrowingGuides/S_purpurea.php
John Brittnacher, Growing Sarracenia, International Carnivorous Plant Society
http://www.carnivorousplants.org/howto/GrowingGuides/Sarracenia.php
